natural problem: A street has 20 houses on each side, for a total of 40 houses. The addresses on the south side of the street form an arithmetic sequence, as do the addresses on the north side of the street. On the south side, the addresses are 4, 10, 16, etc., and on the north side they are 3, 9, 15, etc. A sign painter paints house numbers on a house for $\$1$ per digit. If he paints the appropriate house number once on each of these 40 houses, how many dollars does he collect?
natural solution: Using the formulas for arithmetic sequences, we see that the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the north side is $3+6(20-1)=117$ and the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the south side is $4+6(20-1)=118$. Also, we see that a north side house number is always 3 more than a multiple of 6, and a south side house number is always 4 more than a multiple of 6.

We can then distribute the house numbers for the north and south sides into 3 groups each by the number of digits: \[\text{North side:}\qquad\{3, 9\},\qquad\{15, \ldots, 99\},\qquad\{105, 111, 117\}\] \[\text{South side:}\qquad\{4\},\qquad\{10, \ldots, 94\},\qquad\{100, \ldots, 118\}\] The north side has 2 houses with one digit house numbers, and 3 houses with three digit house numbers, so it must have $20-2-3=15$ houses with two digit house numbers.
The south side has 1 house with one digit house numbers, and 4 houses with three digits house numbers, so it must have $20-1-4=15$ houses with two digit address.
Thus, the total cost is \[(1\times2+2\times15+3\times3)+(1\times1+2\times15+3\times4) = \boxed{84}\] dollars.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes houses :: nat and south :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and north :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and cost :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "houses = 40"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. south n = 4 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. north n = 3 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. cost n = count_digits n"
and h4 : "sum cost (south ` {1..20}) + sum cost (north ` {1..20}) = 84"
shows  "sum cost (south ` {1..houses div 2}) + sum cost (north ` {1..houses div 2}) = 84"

Also, we see that a north side house number is always 3 more than a multiple of 6, and a south side house number is always 4 more than a multiple of 6.
 We can then distribute the house numbers for the north and south sides into 3 groups each by the number of digits: \[\text{North side:}\qquad\{3, 9\},\qquad\{15, \ldots, 99\},\qquad\{105, 111, 117\}\] \[\text{South side:}\qquad\{4\},\qquad\{10, \ldots, 94\},\qquad\{100, \ldots, 118\}\] The north side has 2 houses with one digit house numbers, and 3 houses with three digit house numbers, so it must have $20-2-3=15$ houses with two digit house numbers.

 Thus, the total cost is \[(1\times2+2\times15+3\times3)+(1\times1+2\times15+3\times4) = \boxed{84}\] dollars.

theorem
fixes houses :: nat and south :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and north :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and cost :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "houses = 40"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. south n = 4 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. north n = 3 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. cost n = count_digits n"
and h4 : "sum cost (south ` {1..20}) + sum cost (north ` {1..20}) = 84"
shows  "sum cost (south ` {1..houses div 2}) + sum cost (north ` {1..houses div 2}) = 84"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 40 houses equally divided into two rows, South and North. Each house in the South row is assigned a number according to the formula $4 + 6 * (n - 1)$, and each house in the North row is assigned a number according to the formula $3 + 6 * (n - 1)$, where $n$ is the house number starting from 1. A cost is associated with each house, which is the number of digits in the house's assigned number. If the sum of the costs of all houses in both rows is 84, then the sum of the costs of the first 20 houses in each row is also 84.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i :: nat
assumes h0 : "finite {i. i \<le> 40}"
and h1 : "\<forall>i \<in> {i. i \<le> 20}. card {d. d \<in> set (digits (4 + 6 * (i - 1)))} = 2"
and h2 : "\<forall>i \<in> {i. i > 20 \<and> i \<le> 40}. card {d. d \<in> set (digits (3 + 6 * (i - 21)))} = 2"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>i. card {d. d \<in> set (digits (if i \<le> 20 then 4 + 6 * (i - 1) else 3 + 6 * (i - 21)))}) {i. i \<le> 40} = 84"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A street has 20 houses on each side, for a total of 40 houses. The addresses on the south side of the street form an arithmetic sequence, as do the addresses on the north side of the street. On the south side, the addresses are 4, 10, 16, etc., and on the north side they are 3, 9, 15, etc. A sign painter paints house numbers on a house for $\$1$ per digit. If he paints the appropriate house number once on each of these 40 houses, how many dollars does he collect? The final Answer is 84
 ### Proof
 Using the formulas for arithmetic sequences, we see that the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the north side is $3+6(20-1)=117$ and the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the south side is $4+6(20-1)=118$. Also, we see that a north side house number is always 3 more than a multiple of 6, and a south side house number is always 4 more than a multiple of 6.
 We can then distribute the house numbers for the north and south sides into 3 groups each by the number of digits: \[\text{North side:}\qquad\{3, 9\},\qquad\{15, \ldots, 99\},\qquad\{105, 111, 117\}\] \[\text{South side:}\qquad\{4\},\qquad\{10, \ldots, 94\},\qquad\{100, \ldots, 118\}\] The north side has 2 houses with one digit house numbers, and 3 houses with three digit house numbers, so it must have $20-2-3=15$ houses with two digit house numbers.
 The south side has 1 house with one digit house numbers, and 4 houses with three digits house numbers, so it must have $20-1-4=15$ houses with two digit address.
 Thus, the total cost is \[(1\times2+2\times15+3\times3)+(1\times1+2\times15+3\times4) = \boxed{84}\] dollars.
 *)

theorem
fixes i :: nat
assumes h0 : "finite {i. i \<le> 40}"
and h1 : "\<forall>i \<in> {i. i \<le> 20}. card {d. d \<in> set (digits (4 + 6 * (i - 1)))} = 2"
and h2 : "\<forall>i \<in> {i. i > 20 \<and> i \<le> 40}. card {d. d \<in> set (digits (3 + 6 * (i - 21)))} = 2"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>i. card {d. d \<in> set (digits (if i \<le> 20 then 4 + 6 * (i - 1) else 3 + 6 * (i - 21)))}) {i. i \<le> 40} = 84"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem:
Consider a sequence of numbers where each number is constructed by the following rules: 

1. For the first 20 terms, each number is 4 plus 6 times the (index-1). Each of these numbers has exactly two distinct digits.

2. For the next 20 terms (from the 21st term to the 40th term), each number is 3 plus 6 times the (index-21). Each of these numbers also has exactly two distinct digits. 

What is the total count of distinct digits in all 40 numbers? The final answer is 84.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: real and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 1"
and h1 : "n = 40"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. i \<in> {1..n} \<longrightarrow> (i mod 6 = 0 \<longrightarrow> a = 2) \<and> (i mod 6 \<noteq> 0 \<longrightarrow> a = 1)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>i. a) {1..n} = 84"
a_2.formal solution:

fixes a :: real and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 1"
and h1 : "n = 40"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. i \<in> {1..n} \<longrightarrow> (i mod 6 = 0 \<longrightarrow> a = 2) \<and> (i mod 6 \<noteq> 0 \<longrightarrow> a = 1)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>i. a) {1..n} = 84"

a_2.informal problem: The variable a takes the value 1, except when the index i is a multiple of 6, in which case a takes the value 2. Calculate the sum of a over the first 40 terms. The final answer is 84.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes houses :: nat and south_seq north_seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and cost :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "houses = 40"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. south_seq n = 4 + 6 * n"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. north_seq n = 3 + 6 * n"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. cost n = count_digits n"
and h4 : "cost = (\<lambda>n. if n < 10 then 1 else 2)"
shows  "(\<Sum>n \<in> {0..<houses div 2}. cost (south_seq n) + cost (north_seq n)) = 84"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A street has 20 houses on each side, for a total of 40 houses. The addresses on the south side of the street form an arithmetic sequence, as do the addresses on the north side of the street. On the south side, the addresses are 4, 10, 16, etc., and on the north side they are 3, 9, 15, etc. A sign painter paints house numbers on a house for $\$1$ per digit. fixes houses :: nat and south_seq north_seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and cost :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "houses = 40"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. south_seq n = 4 + 6 * n"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. north_seq n = 3 + 6 * n"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. cost n = count_digits n"
and h4 : "cost = (\<lambda>n. if n < 10 then 1 else 2)"
shows  "(\<Sum>n \<in> {0..<houses div 2}. cost (south_seq n) + cost (north_seq n)) = 84"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem:
There are 40 houses in a street arranged in two rows (one facing south and one facing north). The house numbers for the southern row start at 4 and increase by 6 with each house (for example, the houses are numbered 4, 10, 16, and so on). The house numbers for the northern row start at 3 and increase by 6 with each house. 

The cost associated with a house depends on the number of digits in its house number: it's 1 unit for a one-digit number and 2 units for a two-digit number. 

What is the total cost associated with all the houses? The final answer is 84.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_houses :: nat
and south_seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and north_seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and cost_per_digit :: nat
and sign_painter_cost :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "total_houses = 40"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. south_seq n = 4 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. north_seq n = 3 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h3 : "cost_per_digit = 1"
and h4 : "sign_painter_cost n = cost_per_digit * (num_digits (south_seq n) + num_digits (north_seq n))"
and h5 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..20}. sign_painter_cost n > 0"
shows  "(\<Sum> n = 1..20. sign_painter_cost n) = 84"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A street has 20 houses on each side, for a total of 40 houses. The addresses on the south side of the street form an arithmetic sequence, as do the addresses on the north side of the street. On the south side, the addresses are 4, 10, 16, etc., and on the north side they are 3, 9, 15, etc. A sign painter paints house numbers on a house for $\$1$ per digit. If he paints the appropriate house number once on each of these 40 houses, how many dollars does he collect? The final Answer is 84
 ### Proof
 Using the formulas for arithmetic sequences, we see that the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the north side is $3+6(20-1)=117$ and the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the south side is $4+6(20-1)=118$. Also, we see that a north side house number is always 3 more than a multiple of 6, and a south side house number is always 4 more than a multiple of 6.
 We can then distribute the house numbers for the north and south sides into 3 groups each by the number of digits: \[\text{North side:}\qquad\{3, 9\},\qquad\{15, \ldots, 99\},\qquad\{105, 111, 117\}\] \[\text{South side:}\qquad\{4\},\qquad\{10, \ldots, 94\},\qquad\{100, \ldots, 118\}\] The north side has 2 houses with one digit house numbers, and 3 houses with three digit house numbers, so it must have $20-2-3=15$ houses with two digit house numbers.
 The south side has 1 house with one digit house numbers, and 4 houses with three digits house numbers, so it must have $20-1-4=15$ houses with two digit address.
 Thus, the total cost is \[(1\times2+2\times15+3\times3)+(1\times1+2\times15+3\times4) = \boxed{84}\] dollars.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_houses :: nat
and south_seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and north_seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and cost_per_digit :: nat
and sign_painter_cost :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "total_houses = 40"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. south_seq n = 4 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. north_seq n = 3 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h3 : "cost_per_digit = 1"
and h4 : "sign_painter_cost n = cost_per_digit * (num_digits (south_seq n) + num_digits (north_seq n))"
and h5 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..20}. sign_painter_cost n > 0"
shows  "(\<Sum> n = 1..20. sign_painter_cost n) = 84"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A street has 40 houses, with 20 houses on the north side and 20 houses on the south side. The house numbers on the south side follow the sequence $4 + 6(n - 1)$, and the house numbers on the north side follow the sequence $3 + 6(n - 1)$. A sign painter charges $1 per digit to paint the house numbers. Calculate the total cost of painting all the house numbers on the street. The final answer is $84.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes south_seq north_seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and south_total north_total total :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. south_seq n = 4 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. north_seq n = 3 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h2 : "south_total = (\<Sum>n = 1..20. count_digits (south_seq n))"
and h3 : "north_total = (\<Sum>n = 1..20. count_digits (north_seq n))"
and h4 : "total = south_total + north_total"
shows  "total = 84"
where "count_digits n = (if n < 10 then 1 else 2)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A street has 20 houses on each side, for a total of 40 houses. The addresses on the south side of the street form an arithmetic sequence, as do the addresses on the north side of the street. On the south side, the addresses are 4, 10, 16, etc., and on the north side they are 3, 9, 15, etc. A sign painter paints house numbers on a house for $\$1$ per digit. If he paints the appropriate house number once on each of these 40 houses, how many dollars does he collect? The final Answer is 84
 ### Proof
 Using the formulas for arithmetic sequences, we see that the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the north side is $3+6(20-1)=117$ and the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the south side is $4+6(20-1)=118$. Also, we see that a north side house number is always 3 more than a multiple of 6, and a south side house number is always 4 more than a multiple of 6.
 We can then distribute the house numbers for the north and south sides into 3 groups each by the number of digits: \[\text{North side:}\qquad\{3, 9\},\qquad\{15, \ldots, 99\},\qquad\{105, 111, 117\}\] \[\text{South side:}\qquad\{4\},\qquad\{10, \ldots, 94\},\qquad\{100, \ldots, 118\}\] The north side has 2 houses with one digit house numbers, and 3 houses with three digit house numbers, so it must have $20-2-3=15$ houses with two digit house numbers.
 The south side has 1 house with one digit house numbers, and 4 houses with three digits house numbers, so it must have $20-1-4=15$ houses with two digit address.
 Thus, the total cost is \[(1\times2+2\times15+3\times3)+(1\times1+2\times15+3\times4) = \boxed{84}\] dollars.
 *)

theorem
fixes south_seq north_seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and south_total north_total total :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. south_seq n = 4 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. north_seq n = 3 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h2 : "south_total = (\<Sum>n = 1..20. count_digits (south_seq n))"
and h3 : "north_total = (\<Sum>n = 1..20. count_digits (north_seq n))"
and h4 : "total = south_total + north_total"
shows  "total = 84"
where "count_digits n = (if n < 10 then 1 else 2)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Consider two sequences: the South sequence is defined by $S_n = 4 + 6(n - 1)$, and the North sequence is defined by $N_n = 3 + 6(n - 1)$. Calculate the total number of digits in the first 20 terms of each sequence, and then find the sum of these totals. The final answer is 84.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a_s a_n :: "nat \<Rightarrow> int"
and n_s n_n total_digits :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. a_s n = 4 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. a_n n = 3 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h2 : "n_s = 20"
and h3 : "n_n = 20"
and h4 : "total_digits = (\<Sum>n \<in> {1..n_s}. num_digits (a_s n)) + (\<Sum>n \<in> {1..n_n}. num_digits (a_n n))"
shows  "total_digits = 84"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A street has 20 houses on each side, for a total of 40 houses. The addresses on the south side of the street form an arithmetic sequence, as do the addresses on the north side of the street. On the south side, the addresses are 4, 10, 16, etc., and on the north side they are 3, 9, 15, etc. A sign painter paints house numbers on a house for $\$1$ per digit. If he paints the appropriate house number once on each of these 40 houses, how many dollars does he collect? The final Answer is 84
 ### Proof
 Using the formulas for arithmetic sequences, we see that the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the north side is $3+6(20-1)=117$ and the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the south side is $4+6(20-1)=118$. Also, we see that a north side house number is always 3 more than a multiple of 6, and a south side house number is always 4 more than a multiple of 6.
 We can then distribute the house numbers for the north and south sides into 3 groups each by the number of digits: \[\text{North side:}\qquad\{3, 9\},\qquad\{15, \ldots, 99\},\qquad\{105, 111, 117\}\] \[\text{South side:}\qquad\{4\},\qquad\{10, \ldots, 94\},\qquad\{100, \ldots, 118\}\] The north side has 2 houses with one digit house numbers, and 3 houses with three digit house numbers, so it must have $20-2-3=15$ houses with two digit house numbers.
 The south side has 1 house with one digit house numbers, and 4 houses with three digits house numbers, so it must have $20-1-4=15$ houses with two digit address.
 Thus, the total cost is \[(1\times2+2\times15+3\times3)+(1\times1+2\times15+3\times4) = \boxed{84}\] dollars.
 *)

theorem
fixes a_s a_n :: "nat \<Rightarrow> int"
and n_s n_n total_digits :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. a_s n = 4 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. a_n n = 3 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h2 : "n_s = 20"
and h3 : "n_n = 20"
and h4 : "total_digits = (\<Sum>n \<in> {1..n_s}. num_digits (a_s n)) + (\<Sum>n \<in> {1..n_n}. num_digits (a_n n))"
shows  "total_digits = 84"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: There are two arithmetic sequences: the first one with the formula $a_s(n) = 4 + 6(n - 1)$, and the second one with the formula $a_n(n) = 3 + 6(n - 1)$. Find the total number of digits in the first 20 terms of both sequences combined. The final answer is 84.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes south_side north_side total_houses :: nat
and south_sequence north_sequence :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and cost :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "south_side = 20"
and h1 : "north_side = 20"
and h2 : "total_houses = south_side + north_side"
and h3 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> south_side \<longrightarrow> south_sequence i = 4 + 6 * (i - 1)"
and h4 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> north_side \<longrightarrow> north_sequence i = 3 + 6 * (i - 1)"
and h5 : "\<forall> n. cost n = (\<lambda> n. if n < 10 then 1 else 2) n"
and h6 : "sum (\<lambda> i. cost (south_sequence i)) {1..south_side} + sum (\<lambda> i. cost (north_sequence i)) {1..north_side} = collected_dollars"
shows  "collected_dollars = 84"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A street has 20 houses on each side, for a total of 40 houses. The addresses on the south side of the street form an arithmetic sequence, as do the addresses on the north side of the street. On the south side, the addresses are 4, 10, 16, etc., and on the north side they are 3, 9, 15, etc. A sign painter paints house numbers on a house for $\$1$ per digit. If he paints the appropriate house number once on each of these 40 houses, how many dollars does he collect? The final Answer is 84
 ### Proof
 Using the formulas for arithmetic sequences, we see that the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the north side is $3+6(20-1)=117$ and the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the south side is $4+6(20-1)=118$. Also, we see that a north side house number is always 3 more than a multiple of 6, and a south side house number is always 4 more than a multiple of 6.
 We can then distribute the house numbers for the north and south sides into 3 groups each by the number of digits: \[\text{North side:}\qquad\{3, 9\},\qquad\{15, \ldots, 99\},\qquad\{105, 111, 117\}\] \[\text{South side:}\qquad\{4\},\qquad\{10, \ldots, 94\},\qquad\{100, \ldots, 118\}\] The north side has 2 houses with one digit house numbers, and 3 houses with three digit house numbers, so it must have $20-2-3=15$ houses with two digit house numbers.
 The south side has 1 house with one digit house numbers, and 4 houses with three digits house numbers, so it must have $20-1-4=15$ houses with two digit address.
 Thus, the total cost is \[(1\times2+2\times15+3\times3)+(1\times1+2\times15+3\times4) = \boxed{84}\] dollars.
 *)

theorem
fixes south_side north_side total_houses :: nat
and south_sequence north_sequence :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and cost :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "south_side = 20"
and h1 : "north_side = 20"
and h2 : "total_houses = south_side + north_side"
and h3 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> south_side \<longrightarrow> south_sequence i = 4 + 6 * (i - 1)"
and h4 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> north_side \<longrightarrow> north_sequence i = 3 + 6 * (i - 1)"
and h5 : "\<forall> n. cost n = (\<lambda> n. if n < 10 then 1 else 2) n"
and h6 : "sum (\<lambda> i. cost (south_sequence i)) {1..south_side} + sum (\<lambda> i. cost (north_sequence i)) {1..north_side} = collected_dollars"
shows  "collected_dollars = 84"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a neighborhood, there are 20 houses on the south side and 20 houses on the north side. The house numbers on the south side follow the pattern $4 + 6 * (i - 1)$, where $i$ is the house position, and the house numbers on the north side follow the pattern $3 + 6 * (i - 1)$. The cost of house number $n$ is 1 dollar if the house number is less than 10 and 2 dollars otherwise. Calculate the total amount of dollars collected from all the houses in the neighborhood. The final answer is 84 dollars.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes s n i :: nat
and south_seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and north_seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. south_seq i = 4 + 6 * (i - 1)"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. north_seq i = 3 + 6 * (i - 1)"
and h2 : "s = (\<Sum>i=1..20. num_digits (south_seq i))"
and h3 : "n = (\<Sum>i=1..20. num_digits (north_seq i))"
shows  "s + n = 84"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A street has 20 houses on each side, for a total of 40 houses. The addresses on the south side of the street form an arithmetic sequence, as do the addresses on the north side of the street. On the south side, the addresses are 4, 10, 16, etc., and on the north side they are 3, 9, 15, etc. A sign painter paints house numbers on a house for $\$1$ per digit. If he paints the appropriate house number once on each of these 40 houses, how many dollars does he collect? The final Answer is 84
 ### Proof
 Using the formulas for arithmetic sequences, we see that the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the north side is $3+6(20-1)=117$ and the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the south side is $4+6(20-1)=118$. Also, we see that a north side house number is always 3 more than a multiple of 6, and a south side house number is always 4 more than a multiple of 6.
 We can then distribute the house numbers for the north and south sides into 3 groups each by the number of digits: \[\text{North side:}\qquad\{3, 9\},\qquad\{15, \ldots, 99\},\qquad\{105, 111, 117\}\] \[\text{South side:}\qquad\{4\},\qquad\{10, \ldots, 94\},\qquad\{100, \ldots, 118\}\] The north side has 2 houses with one digit house numbers, and 3 houses with three digit house numbers, so it must have $20-2-3=15$ houses with two digit house numbers.
 The south side has 1 house with one digit house numbers, and 4 houses with three digits house numbers, so it must have $20-1-4=15$ houses with two digit address.
 Thus, the total cost is \[(1\times2+2\times15+3\times3)+(1\times1+2\times15+3\times4) = \boxed{84}\] dollars.
 *)

theorem
fixes s n i :: nat
and south_seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and north_seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. south_seq i = 4 + 6 * (i - 1)"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. north_seq i = 3 + 6 * (i - 1)"
and h2 : "s = (\<Sum>i=1..20. num_digits (south_seq i))"
and h3 : "n = (\<Sum>i=1..20. num_digits (north_seq i))"
shows  "s + n = 84"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider the sequences of numbers: the "south" sequence is given by $4 + 6(i - 1)$, and the "north" sequence is given by $3 + 6(i - 1)$, for each natural number $i$. Calculate the total number of digits in the first 20 terms of both sequences combined. The final answer is 84.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes south_north_seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and total_houses :: nat
and south_address :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and north_address :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and digit_cost :: nat
and total_cost :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_houses = 40"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. south_address n = 4 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. north_address n = 3 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h3 : "digit_cost = 1"
and h4 : "total_cost = (\<Sum>n \<in> {1..20}. digit_cost * (num_digits (south_address n) + num_digits (north_address n)))"
shows  "total_cost = 84"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A street has 20 houses on each side, for a total of 40 houses. The addresses on the south side of the street form an arithmetic sequence, as do the addresses on the north side of the street. On the south side, the addresses are 4, 10, 16, etc., and on the north side they are 3, 9, 15, etc. A sign painter paints house numbers on a house for $\$1$ per digit. If he paints the appropriate house number once on each of these 40 houses, how many dollars does he collect? The final Answer is 84
 ### Proof
 Using the formulas for arithmetic sequences, we see that the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the north side is $3+6(20-1)=117$ and the $20^{\text{th}}$ number for the south side is $4+6(20-1)=118$. Also, we see that a north side house number is always 3 more than a multiple of 6, and a south side house number is always 4 more than a multiple of 6.
 We can then distribute the house numbers for the north and south sides into 3 groups each by the number of digits: \[\text{North side:}\qquad\{3, 9\},\qquad\{15, \ldots, 99\},\qquad\{105, 111, 117\}\] \[\text{South side:}\qquad\{4\},\qquad\{10, \ldots, 94\},\qquad\{100, \ldots, 118\}\] The north side has 2 houses with one digit house numbers, and 3 houses with three digit house numbers, so it must have $20-2-3=15$ houses with two digit house numbers.
 The south side has 1 house with one digit house numbers, and 4 houses with three digits house numbers, so it must have $20-1-4=15$ houses with two digit address.
 Thus, the total cost is \[(1\times2+2\times15+3\times3)+(1\times1+2\times15+3\times4) = \boxed{84}\] dollars.
 *)

theorem
fixes south_north_seq :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and total_houses :: nat
and south_address :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and north_address :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and digit_cost :: nat
and total_cost :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_houses = 40"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. south_address n = 4 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. north_address n = 3 + 6 * (n - 1)"
and h3 : "digit_cost = 1"
and h4 : "total_cost = (\<Sum>n \<in> {1..20}. digit_cost * (num_digits (south_address n) + num_digits (north_address n)))"
shows  "total_cost = 84"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: There are 40 houses on a street, with 20 houses on the south side and 20 houses on the north side. The house numbers on the south side of the street follow the pattern $4 + 6(n - 1)$, where $n$ is the house position from the start of the street. The house numbers on the north side of the street follow the pattern $3 + 6(n - 1)$. If the cost to paint each digit of the house numbers is $1, calculate the total cost to paint all the house numbers on the street. The final answer is $84$.
